triples.name: AdaBoost
triples.relevance: AdaBoost is an adaptive boosting ensemble method used to combine weak learners into a strong classifier.

triples.name: Random forest
triples.relevance: Random Forest is an ensemble learning method that combines multiple decision trees for improved classification performance.

triples.name: Cross-validation (statistics)
triples.relevance: K-Fold Cross Validation is a statistical method used to evaluate machine learning models and estimate their generalization error.

triples.name: Synthetic minority oversampling technique
triples.relevance: SMOTE is a data preprocessing technique used to handle imbalanced datasets by oversampling the minority class.

triples.name: Naive Bayes classifier
triples.relevance: Naive Bayes is a probabilistic classification algorithm based on Bayes' theorem used as a base classifier.

triples.name: Decision tree learning
triples.relevance: Decision Trees are supervised learning algorithms used for classification and as base learners in ensemble methods.

triples.name: Ensemble learning
triples.relevance: Ensemble learning combines multiple machine learning models to achieve better predictive performance than individual models.

triples.name: Machine learning
triples.relevance: Machine Learning is the field of study concerned with developing algorithms that learn from data.

triples.name: Data preprocessing
triples.relevance: Data Preprocessing involves cleaning and transforming raw data to improve quality before analysis and model training.

triples.name: AdaBoost-Random Forest
triples.relevance: The paper proposes combining AdaBoost with Random Forest ensemble method achieving 95.47% accuracy for early heart disease detection.
